Award.AwardTitle: New Approaches for the Design of Particulate Media

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1605075
PI: Jaeger, Heinrich

Particulate media, or granular materials, are random aggregates of a large number of solid particles. They come in all sizes and encompass a broad range of naturally occurring materials, such as gravel, sand, and soil, and a broad range of industrial and agricultural products, such as grains, fertilizers and powders, and pigments. These materials pose special challenges to handle on a large scale because they can exhibit an array of solid-like and fluid-like behaviors. A key question in designing such materials is how to pick the constituent particles to achieve desired material properties of the aggregate. This project will develop a new approach that will allow practitioners to engineer particle types that will yield predetermined, target outcomes for the behavior of the aggregate. The project will involve a combination of computations and experiments to solve the problem of particle design and to develop a set of general design rules. The project will provide opportunities for students at all academic levels to participate in research. The researchers will participate in a Bridge Program that encourages undergraduates, especially those from underrepresented groups, to continue to graduate work. In addition, the team will participate in several outreach activities to increase the public's appreciation of science and engineering, including the Physics with a Bang! event, which demonstrates science principles to broad audiences.

To tackle the inverse problem of identifying appropriate particle shapes for given performance targets, the project implements a computer-aided design and optimization method that makes use of ideas from evolutionary computation. Going beyond devising specific solutions to specific design targets, the project introduces new capabilities by developing general design rules. Such rules apply across a whole range of related targets and, once established, enable rational design by providing a mapping from overall behavior of the particulate medium to particle-level attributes, such as shape. For the design of random composite or particulate systems with complex particle shapes this is a new approach with transformative potential. In this project,arbitrary convex and non-convex shapes will be represented by sets of bonded spheres of varying radius and overlap, whose configuration can be mutated and evolved to optimize performance. Directions to be investigated include distributions of particle sizes and shapes, particle breakage, particles combining hard and soft materials, designing the stress response in the nonlinear regime of incipient failure, and optimizing not only the particles but also the processing pathway. In a second stage of the project this methodology is extended to designing flow behavior, focusing on concentrated particle suspensions. For calibration and validation the computational effort is closely coupled to systematic experiments that use high-resolution 3d-printing to fabricate particles and use x-rays and ultrasound for non-invasive imaging.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Particulate media, also called granular materials, are random agglomerates of a large number of macroscopic, individually solid particles. They come in all sizes and encompass a wide range from sand, gravel, or soil to agricultural products like grain or fertilizer, to pigments, pharmaceutical powders or ultrafine particulates for additive manufacturing. While often a bulk commodity comprised of seemingly simple ingredients, granular materials can exhibit remarkably complex behavior during storage, handling and processing. In particular, granular materials can flow like liquids yet can also behave rigidly like solids. More often, they exhibit intermediate behavior that is not fully captured by either category. Much of this complexity emerges from the way individual particles interact when come into contact and thus depends significantly on particle shape. For applications where either the performance of the material is critical or the fabrication cost of the individual particles is substantial, it therefore is important to ask: What kind of particle shape should be picked in order to optimize a particular overall property of the granular material? 

Finding answers to this question constitutes a major intellectual challenge and was the overarching goal of this project.  Three specific contexts were investigated. First, on large, architectural scales we introduced and demonstrated the new concept of aleatory construction, which enables fabrication of slender vertical columns and even arches from suitable shaped particles without requiring any fasteners or cementing, simply by virtue of the capabilities of the particles to entangle as they are pushed together. Such aleatory construction based on particle jamming opens up new possibilities for rapid deployment of load-bearing structures, which after their use are fully recyclable and reusable. Second, we investigated how the eventual failure, and subsequent recovery, of granular agglomerates under increasing mechanical loading depends on the particle shape. Studying over 20 different shapes we identified which class of shapes tends to produce mainly small failure events or lead to large volatility similar to large stock market fluctuations. These findings are important not only for the design of particulate media with desired failure modes, but provide stringent new benchmarks on which to test current theoretical models that describe in general terms how disordered, amorphous materials yield and fail under applied strain.  Third, we developed and applied computational methods based on machine learning as a powerful new path toward identifying, out of a myriad of possible particle shapes, those that will produce specific, targeted behavior for the granular agglomerate as a whole.  Two graduate students, four undergraduates, and two high school students received forefront research training. Both graduate students received their Ph.D. while working on this project.
